Award.AbstractNarration:
The program builds upon the breakthroughs made in improving the efficiency of light and mechanical energy harvesting at NSF I/UCRC: Center for Energy Harvesting Materials and Systems (CEHMS). Sun light and natural wave oscillations are promising source of energy for recharging the onboard batteries. Current photovoltaic conversion technologies have challenges in terms of material utilization, long term stability, conversion efficiency, energy storage density and most importantly cost competitiveness ($/Watt). Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) have been shown to be better alternative if price/performance ratio is compared. DSSC can absorb diffused sunlight and can convert it efficiently into electricity. DSSCs can also work in cloudy weather and low-light conditions. Efforts will be made towards integration of the DSSC module with the bell of the proposes robot without affecting the rowing propulsion mechanism. Secondly, non-linear magnetic levitation based inductive energy harvester will be incorporated in the appendages of the robot to harvest the wave energy.

The team has the expertise and knowledge and desire required to develop the Bio-inspired Underwater Surveillance Vehicle (BUSV). The outcome of the I-Corps project will be technology demonstration and a clear go/no go decision regarding viability of BUSV. If successful, a spin-off company resulting from the I-Corps effort will lead to creation of high tech ? high paying jobs and contribute to the national economy. In addition to many defense applications, civilian industries related to water quality sensing, pollution monitoring, chemical spill such as oil spills cleaning, and robotic aquariums will benefit from the proposed technology.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the program was to identify the commercial potential of biomimetic underwater surveillance vehicles inspired by jellyfish incombination with flexible dye-sensitized solar cells. The main goal of the program was to evaluate the possibility of a new start-up business based upon the solar powered underwater vehicles. In parallel to evaluating the business model, we also worked on the demonstration prototype that can be presented to the potential investors.

Several key lessons were learned through the progress of the I-Corps program. The first is the importance of interviews. Talking face-to face to people in different sectors of the business model provide significant information which can prove or disprove hypothesis made. This can lead to major savings in money and time. Secondly, we learned the significance of creating a business model or business canvas to better understand and communicate the different aspects of a company. Having a good product is not enough and the business canvas highlights the other important aspects which can create a bottle neck to commercializing a technology. Lastly, we found that our technology had some commercial potential but not in the way we had expected. New value propositions need to be included and our technology adapted before bringing our product to market. We believe there is a significant business opportunity with our technology but that a strategic procedure of starting with commercial aquariums and moving on to high-end personal aquariums before entering the larger toy market. Currently, the team is working on the SBIR proposals and other funding opportunities to launch the company.


Last Modified: 10/17/2013
Modified by: Danesh K Tafti

    Alex Villanueva and Shashank Priya

    Structure of the Robotic Jellyfish
